line: (giving up again). Nothing to be done.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (advancing with short, stiff strides, legs wide apart). I'm beginning to come round to that opinion. All my life I've tried to put it from me, saying Vladimir, be reasonable, you haven't yet tried everything. And I resumed the struggle. (He broods, musing on the struggle. Turning to Estragon.) So there you are again.ESTRAGON: Am I?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I'm glad to see you back. I thought you were gone forever.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Together again at last! We'll have to celebrate this. But how? (He reflects.) Get up till I embrace you.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (hurt, coldly). May one inquire where His Highness spent the night?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Beat me? Certainly they beat me.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: The same lot as usual? ESTRAGON:The same? I don't know.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: When I think of it . . . all these years . . . but for me . . . where would you be . . . (Decisively.) You'd be nothing more than a little heap of bones at the present minute, no doubt about it.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (gloomily). It's too much for one man. (Pause. Cheerfully.) On the other hand what's the good of losing heart now, that's what I say. We should have thought of it a million years ago, in the nineties.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Ah stop blathering and help me off with this bloody thing.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Hand in hand from the top of the Eiffel Tower, among the first. We were respectable in those days. Now it's too late. They wouldn't even let us up. (Estragon tears at his boot.) What are you doing?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Taking off my boot. Did that never happen to you?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Boots must be taken off every day, I'm tired telling you that. Why don't you listen to me?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: It hurts? ESTRAGON:(angrily). Hurts! He wants to know if it hurts!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (angrily). No one ever suffers but you. I don't count. I'd like to hear what you'd say if you had what I have.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (angrily). Hurts! He wants to know if it hurts!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (pointing). You might button it all the same.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (stooping). True. (He buttons his fly.) Never neglect the little things of life.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: What do you expect, you always wait till the last moment.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (musingly). The last moment . . . (He meditates.) Hope deferred maketh the something sick, who said that?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Sometimes I feel it coming all the same. Then I go all queer. (He takes off his hat, peers inside it, feels about inside it, shakes it, puts it on again.) How shall I say? Relieved and at the same time . . . (he searches for the word) . . . appalled. (With emphasis.) AP-PALLED. (He takes off his hat again, peers inside it.) Funny. (He knocks on the crown as though to dislodge a foreign body, peers into it again, puts it on again.) Nothing to be done. (Estragon with a supreme effort succeeds in pulling off his boot. He peers inside it, feels about inside it, turns it upsidedown, shakes it, looks on the ground to see if anything has fallen out, finds nothing, feels inside it again, staring sightlessly before him.) Well?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Try and put it on again.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (examining his foot). I'll air it for a bit.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: There's man all over for you, blaming on his boots the faults of his feet. (He takes off his hat again, peers inside it, feels about inside it, knocks on the crown, blows into it, puts it on again.) This is getting alarming. (Silence. Vladimir deep in thought, Estragon pulling at his toes.) One of the thieves was saved. (Pause.) It's a reasonable percentage. (Pause.) Gogo.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Oh . . . (He reflects.) We wouldn't have to go into the details. ESTRAGON:Our being born? Vladimir breaks into a hearty laugh which he immediately stifles, his hand pressed to his pubis, his face contorted.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: One daren't even laugh any more.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Merely smile. (He smiles suddenly from ear to ear, keeps smiling, ceases as suddenly.) It's not the same thing. Nothing to be done. (Pause.) Gogo.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Did you ever read the Bible?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: The Bible . . . (He reflects.) I must have taken a look at it.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I remember the maps of the Holy Land. Coloured they were. Very pretty. The Dead Sea was pale blue. The very look of it made me thirsty. That's where we'll go, I used to say, that's where we'll go for our honeymoon. We'll swim. We'll be happy.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You should have been a poet.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I was. (Gesture towards his rags.) Isn't that obvious?Silence.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Where was I . . . How's your foot?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Ah yes, the two thieves. Do you remember the story?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Shall I tell it to you?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: It'll pass the time. (Pause.) Two thieves, crucified at the same time as our Saviour. One—
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Our Saviour. Two thieves. One is supposed to have been saved and the other . . . (he searches for the contrary of saved) . . . damned.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Hell. ESTRAGON:I'm going. He does not move.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: And yet . . . (pause) . . . how is it –this is not boring you I hope– how is it that of the four Evangelists only one speaks of a thief being saved. The four of them were there –or thereabouts– and only one speaks of a thief being saved. (Pause.) Come on, Gogo, return the ball, can't you, once in a while?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (with exaggerated enthusiasm). I find this really most extraordinarily interesting.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: One out of four. Of the other three, two don't mention any thieves at all and the third says that both of them abused him.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: What's all this about? Abused who?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Then the two of them must have been damned.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: But one of the four says that one of the two was saved.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Well? They don't agree and that's all there is to it.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: But all four were there. And only one speaks of a thief being saved. Why believe him rather than the others?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Everybody. It's the only version they know.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: People are bloody ignorant apes. He rises painfully, goes limping to extreme left, halts, gazes into distance off with his hand screening his eyes, turns, goesto extreme right, gazes into distance. Vladimir watches him, then goes and picks up the boot, peers into it, drops it hastily.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Pah! He spits. Estragon moves to center, halts with his back to auditorium.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Charming spot. (He turns, advances to front, halts facing auditorium.) Inspiring prospects. (He turns to Vladimir.) Let's go.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (despairingly). Ah! (Pause.) You're sure it was here?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: He said by the tree. (They look at the tree.) Do you see any others?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: What is it? VLADIMIR:I don't know. A willow.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Or perhaps it's not the season.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Looks to me more like a bush.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: A—. What are you insinuating? That we've come to the wrong place?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: He didn't say for sure he'd come.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: We'll come back tomorrow. ESTRAGON:And then the day after tomorrow.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Why . . . (Angrily.) Nothing is certain when you're about.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: In my opinion we were here.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (looking round). You recognize the place?ESTRAGON: I didn't say that.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: All the same . . . that tree . . . (turning towards auditorium) that bog . . .
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You're sure it was this evening?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I must have made a note of it. (He fumbles in his pockets, bursting with miscellaneous rubbish.)
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (very insidious). But what Saturday? And is it Saturday? Is it not rather Sunday? (Pause.) Or Monday? (Pause.) Or Friday?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (looking wildly about him, as though the date was inscribed in the landscape). It's not possible!ESTRAGON: Or Thursday?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: If he came yesterday and we weren't here you may be sure he won't come again today.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: But you say we were here yesterday.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I may be mistaken. (Pause.) Let's stop talking for a minute, do you mind?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (feebly). All right. (Estragon sits down on the mound. Vladimir paces agitatedly to and fro, halting from time to time to gaze into distance off. Estragon falls asleep. Vladimir halts finally before Estragon.) Gogo! . . . Gogo! . . . GOGO! Estragon wakes with a start.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (restored to the horror of his situation). I was asleep! (Despairingly.) Why will you never let me sleep?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Don't tell me! ESTRAGON:I dreamt that—
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (gesture toward the universe). This one is enough for you? (Silence.) It's not nice of you, Didi. Who am I to tell my private nightmares to if I can't tell them to you?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Let them remain private. You know I can't bear that.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (coldly.) There are times when I wonder if it wouldn't be better for us to part.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: That would be too bad, really too bad. (Pause.) Wouldn't it, Didi, be really too bad? (Pause.) When you think of the beauty of the way. (Pause.) And the goodness of the wayfarers. (Pause. Wheedling.) Wouldn't it, Didi?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (voluptuously.) Calm . . . calm . . . The English say cawm. (Pause.) You know the story of the Englishman in the brothel?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Tell it to me. VLADIMIR:Ah stop it!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: An Englishman having drunk a little more than usual proceeds to a brothel. The bawd asks him if he wants a fair one, a dark one or a red-haired one. Go on.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: STOP IT! Exit Vladimir hurriedly. Estragon gets up and follows him as far as the limit of the stage. Gestures of Estragon like those of a spectator encouraging a pugilist. Enter Vladimir. He brushes past Estragon, crosses the stage with bowed head. Estragon takes a step towards him, halts.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (gently.) You wanted to speak to me? (Silence. Estragon takes a step forward.) You had something to say to me? (Silence. Another step forward.) Didi . . .
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (without turning). I've nothing to say to you.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (step forward). You're angry? (Silence. Step forward). Forgive me. (Silence. Step forward. Estragon lays his hand on Vladimir's shoulder.) Come, Didi. (Silence.) Give me your hand. (Vladimir half turns.) Embrace me! (Vladimir stiffens.) Don't be stubborn! (Vladimir softens. They embrace. # Estragon recoils.) You stink of garlic!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: It's for the kidneys. (Silence. Estragon looks attentively at the tree.) What do we do now?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Hmm. It'd give us an erection.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: With all that follows. Where it falls mandrakes grow. That's why they shriek when you pull them up. Did you not know that?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: From a bough? (They go towards the tree.) I wouldn't trust it.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Why me? VLADIMIR:You're lighter than I am.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Use your intelligence, can't you? Vladimir uses his intelligence.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: This is how it is. (He reflects.) The bough . . . the bough . . . (Angrily.) Use your head, can't you?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (with effort). Gogo light—bough not break—Gogo dead. Didi heavy—bough break—Didi alone. Whereas—
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: If it hangs you it'll hang anything.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: But am I heavier than you?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: So you tell me. I don't know. There's an even chance. Or nearly.VLADIMIR: Well? What do we do?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Don't let's do anything. It's safer.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Let's wait and see what he says.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Let's wait till we know exactly how we stand.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: On the other hand it might be better to strike the iron before it freezes.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I'm curious to hear what he has to offer. Then we'll take it or leave it.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: What exactly did we ask him for?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I can't have been listening. VLADIMIR:Oh . . . Nothing very definite.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: That he'd have to think it over.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: In the quiet of his home.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Come in? On our hands and knees.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Your Worship wishes to assert his prerogatives?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: We've no rights any more? Laugh of Vladimir, stifled as before, less the smile.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You'd make me laugh if it wasn't prohibited.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (distinctly). We got rid of them. Silence. They remain motionless, arms dangling, heads sunk, sagging at the knees.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I hear nothing. VLADIMIR:Hsst! (They listen. Estragon loses his balance, almost falls. He clutches the arm of Vladimir, who totters. They listen, huddled together.) Nor I. Sighs of relief. They relax and separate.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Pah! The wind in the reeds.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I could have sworn I heard shouts.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Is that all there is?VLADIMIR: I might have some turnips.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Give me a carrot. (Vladimir rummages in his pockets, takes out a turnip and gives it to Estragon who takes a bite out of it. Angrily.) It's a turnip!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Oh pardon! I could have sworn it was a carrot. (He rummages again in his pockets, finds nothing but turnips.) All that's turnips. (He rummages.) You must have eaten the last. (He rummages.) Wait, I have it. (He brings out a carrot and gives it to Estragon.) There, dear fellow. (Estragon wipes the carrot on his sleeve and begins to eat it.) Make it last, that's the end of them.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: So much the better, so much the better. (Pause.) What was it you wanted to know? ESTRAGON:I've forgotten. (Chews.) That's what annoys me. (He looks at the carrot appreciatively, dangles it between finger and thumb.) I'll never forget this carrot. (He sucks the end of it meditatively.) Ah yes, now I remember.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (his mouth full, vacuously). We're not tied?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I don't hear a word you're saying.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (chews, swallows). I'm asking you if we're tied.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: To Godot? Tied to Godot! What an idea! No question of it. (Pause.) For the moment. ESTRAGON:His name is Godot?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Fancy that. (He raises what remains of the carrot by the stub of leaf, twirls it before his eyes.) Funny, the more you eat the worse it gets.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: With me it's just the opposite.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I get used to the muck as I go along.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (after prolonged reflection). Is that the opposite?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Nothing you can do about it.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: No use wriggling.VLADIMIR: The essential doesn't change.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Nothing to be done. (He proffers the remains of the carrot to Vladimir.) Like to finish it? A terrible cry, close at hand. Estragon drops the carrot. They remain motionless, then together make a sudden rush towards the wings. Estragon stops halfway, runs back, picks up the carrot, stuffs it in his pocket, runs to rejoin Vladimir who is waiting for him, stops again, runs back, picks up his boot, runs to rejoin Vladimir. Huddled together, shoulders hunched, cringing away from the menace, they wait. # Enter Pozzo and Lucky. Pozzo drives Lucky by means of a rope passed round his neck, so that Lucky is the first to enter, followed by the rope which is long enough to let him reach the middle of the stage before Pozzo appears. Lucky carries a heavy bag, a folding stool, a picnic basket and a greatcoat, Pozzo a whip.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (off). On! (Crack of whip. Pozzo appears. They cross the stage. Lucky passes before Vladimir and Estragon and exit. Pozzo at the sight of Vladimir and Estragon stops short. The rope tautens. Pozzo jerks at it violently.) Back! Noise of Lucky falling with all his baggage. Vladimir and Estragon turn towards him, half wishing half fearing to go to his assistance. Vlamdimir takes a step towards Lucky, Estragon holds him back by the sleeve.
speaker: POZZO

line: Stay where you are!POZZO: Be careful! He's wicked. (Vladimir and Estragon turn towards Pozzo.) With strangers.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (timidly, to Pozzo). You're not Mr. Godot, Sir?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (terrifying voice). I am Pozzo! (Silence.) Pozzo! (Silence.) Does that name mean nothing to you? (Silence.) I say does that name mean nothing to you?Vladimir and Estragon look at each other questioningly.
speaker: POZZO

line: Ah! Pozzo . . . let me see . . . Pozzo . . .
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Pozzo . . . no . . . I'm afraid I . . . no . . . I don't seem to . . . Pozzo advances threateningly.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (conciliating). I once knew a family called Gozzo. The mother had the clap.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (hastily). We're not from these parts, Sir.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (halting). You are human beings none the less. (He puts on his glasses.) As far as one can see. (He takes off his glasses.) Of the same species as myself. (He bursts into an enormous laugh.) Of the same species as Pozzo! Made in God's image!
speaker: POZZO

line: Oh no, Sir, not for an instant, Sir.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Oh he's a . . . he's a kind of acquaintance.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Nothing of the kind, we hardly know him.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: True . . . we don't know him very well . . . but all the same . . .
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Personally, I wouldn't even know him if I saw him.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (recoiling before Pozzo). That's to say . . . you understand . . . the dusk . . . the strain . . . waiting . . . I confess . . . I imagined . . . for a second . . .
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Waiting? So you were waiting for him?
speaker: POZZO

line: Well you see— POZZO:Here? On my land?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: The road is free to all.
speaker: POZZO

line: That's how we looked at it.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: It's a disgrace. But there you are.
speaker: POZZO

line: Nothing we can do about it.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (with magnanimous gesture). Let's say no more about it. (He jerks the rope.) Up pig! (Pause.) Every time he drops he falls asleep. (Jerks the rope.) Up hog! (Noise of Lucky getting up and picking up his baggage. Pozzo jerks the rope.) Back! (Enter Lucky backwards.) Stop! (Lucky stops.) Turn! (Lucky turns. To Vladimir and Estragon, affably.) Gentlemen, I am happy to have met you. (Before their incredulous expression.) Yes yes, sincerely happy. (He jerks the rope.) Closer! (Lucky advances.) Stop! (Lucky stops.) Yes, the road seems long when one journeys all alone for . . . (he consults his watch) . . . yes . . . (he calculates) . . . yes, six hours, that's right, six hours on end, and never a soul in sight. (To Lucky.) Coat! (Lucky puts down the bag, advances, gives the coat, goes back to his place, takes up the bag.) Hold that! (Pozzo holds out the whip. Lucky advances and, both his hands being occupied, takes the whip in his mouth, then goes back to his place. Pozzo begins to put on his coat, stops.) Coat! (Lucky puts down the bag, basket and stool,helps Pozzo on with his coat, goes back to his place and takes up bag, basket and stool.) Touch of autumn in the air this evening. (Pozzo finishes buttoning up his coat, stoops, inspects himself, straightens up.) Whip! (Lucky advances, stoops, Pozzo snatches the whip from his mouth, Lucky goes back to his place.) Yes, gentlemen, I cannot go for long without the society of my likes (he puts on his glasses and looks at the two likes) even when the likeness is an imperfect one. (He takes off his glasses.) Stool! (Lucky puts down bag and basket, advances, opens stool, puts it down, goes back to his place, takes up bag and basket.) Closer! (Lucky puts down bag and basket, advances, moves stool, goes back to his place, takes up bag and basket. Pozzo sits down, places the butt of his whip against Lucky's chest and pushes.) Back! (Lucky takes a step back.) Further! (Lucky takes another step back.) Stop! (Lucky stops. To Vladimir and Estragon.) That is why, with your permission, I propose to dally with you a moment, before I venture any further. Basket! (Lucky advances, gives the basket, goes back to his place.) The fresh air stimulates the jaded appetite. (He opens the basket, takes out a piece of chicken and a bottle of wine.) Basket! (Lucky advances, picks up the basket and goes back to his place.) Further! (Lucky takes a step back.) He stinks. Happy days! He drinks from the bottle, puts it down and begins to eat. Silence. # Vladimir and Estragon, cautiously at first, then more boldly, begin to circle about Lucky, inspecting him up and down. Pozzo eats his chicken voraciously, throwing away the bones after having sucked them. Lucky sags slowly, until bag and basket touch the ground, then straightens up with a start and begins to sag again. Rhythm of one sleeping on his feet.
speaker: POZZO

line: What ails him? VLADIMIR:He looks tired.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Why doesn't he put down his bags?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: How do I know? (They close in on him.) Careful!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (looking at the neck). I see nothing.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Here. Estragon goes over beside Vladimir.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: It's the chafing. They resume their inspection, dwell on the face.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (shrugging his shoulders, wry face.) Would you say so?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Looks like his last gasp to me.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: It's not certain. (Pause.) Ask him a question.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Would that be a good thing?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Leave him in peace! (They turn toward Pozzo who, having finished eating, wipes his mouth with the back of his hand.) Can't you see he wants to rest? Basket! (He strikes a matchand begins to light his pipe. Estragon sees the chicken bones on the ground and stares at them greedily. As Lucky does not move Pozzo throws the match angrily away and jerks the rope.) Basket! (Lucky starts, almost falls, recovers his senses, advances, puts the bottle in the basket and goes back to his place. Estragon stares at the bones. Pozzo strikes another match and lights his pipe.) What can you expect, it's not his job. (He pulls at his pipe, stretches out his legs.) Ah! That's better.
speaker: POZZO

line: What is it, my good man?
speaker: POZZO

line: Er . . . you've finished with the . . . er . . . you don't need the . . . er . . . bones, Sir?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: No no, he does well to ask. Do I need the bones? (He turns them over with the end of his whip.) No, personally I do not need them any more. (Estragon takes a step towards the bones.) But . . . (Estragon stops short) . . . but in theory the bones go to the carrier. He is therefore the one to ask. (Estragon turns towards Lucky, hesitates.) Go on, go on, don't be afraid, ask him, he'll tell you. Estragon goes towards Lucky, stops before him.
speaker: POZZO

line: Mister . . . excuse me, Mister . . . POZZO:You're being spoken to, pig! Reply! (To Estragon.) Try him again.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Excuse me, Mister, the bones, you won't be wanting the bones? Lucky looks long at Estragon.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (in raptures). Mister! (Lucky bows his head.) Reply! Do you want them or don't you? (Silence of Lucky. To Estragon.) They're yours. (Estragon makes a dart at the bones, picks them up and begins to gnaw them.) I don't like it. I've never known him to refuse a bone before. (He looks anxiously at Lucky.) Nice business it'd be if he fell sick on me! He puffs at his pipe.
speaker: POZZO

line: (exploding). It's a scandal! Silence. Flabbergasted, Estragon stops gnawing, looks at Pozzo and Vladimir in turn. Pozzo outwardly calm. Vladimir embarrassed.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (To Vladimir). Are you alluding to anything in particular?
speaker: POZZO

line: (stutteringly resolute). To treat a man . . . (gesture towards Lucky) . . . like that . . . I think that . . . no . . . a human being . . . no . . . it's a scandal!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (not to be outdone). A disgrace! He resumes his gnawing. POZZO:You are severe. (To Vladimir.) What age are you, if it's not a rude question? (Silence.) Sixty? Seventy? (To Estragon.) What age would you say he was?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I am impertinent. (He knocks out his pipe against the whip, gets up.) I must be getting on. Thank you for your society. (He reflects.) Unless I smoke another pipe before I go. What do you say? (They say nothing.) Oh I'm only a small smoker, a very small smoker, I'm not in the habit of smoking two pipes one on top of the other, it makes (hand to heart, sighing) my heart go pit-a-pat. (Silence.) It's the nicotine, one absorbs it in spite of one's precautions. (Sighs.) You know how it is. (Silence.) But perhaps you don't smoke? Yes? No? It's of no importance. (Silence.) But how am I to sit down now, without affectation, now that I have risen? Without appearing to –how shall I say– without appearing to falter. (To Vladimir.) I beg your pardon? (Silence.) Perhaps you didn't speak? (Silence.) It's of no importance. Let me see . . . He reflects.
speaker: POZZO

line: Ah! That's better. He puts the bones in his pocket.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: So soon? POZZO:One moment! (He jerks the rope.) Stool! (He points with his whip. Lucky moves the stool.) More! There! (He sits down. Lucky goes back to his place.) Done it! He fills his pipe.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I hope I'm not driving you away. Wait a little longer, you'll never regret it.
speaker: POZZO

line: (having lit his pipe). The second is never so sweet . . . (he takes the pipe out of his mouth, contemplates it) . . . as the first I mean. (He puts the pipe back in his mouth.) But it's sweet just the same.
speaker: POZZO

line: He can no longer endure my presence. I am perhaps not particularly human, but who cares? (To Vladimir.) Think twice before you do anything rash. Suppose you go now while it is still day, for there is no denying it is still day. (They all look up at the sky.) Good. (They stop looking at the sky.) What happens in that case– (he takes the pipe out of his mouth, examines it) – I'm out– (he relights his pipe) –in that case– (puff) –in that case– (puff) –what happens in that case to your appointment with this . . . Godet . . . Godot . . . Godin . . . anyhow you see who I mean, who has your future in his hands . . . (pause) . . . at least your immediate future? VLADIMIR:Who told you?
speaker: POZZO

line: He speaks to me again! If this goes on much longer we'll soon be old friends.
speaker: POZZO

line: Why doesn't he put down his bags?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I too would be happy to meet him. The more people I meet the happier I become. From the meanest creature one departs wiser, richer, more conscious of one's blessings. Even you . . . (he looks at them ostentatiously in turn to make it clear they are both meant) . . . even you, who knows, will have added to my store.
speaker: POZZO

line: Why doesn't he put down his bags?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (delighted). A question! Who? What? A moment ago you were calling me Sir, in fear and trembling. Now you're asking me questions. No good will come of this!
speaker: POZZO

line: You can ask him now. He's on the alert.ESTRAGON: Ask him what?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Why he doesn't put down his bags.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (who has followed these exchanges with anxious attention, fearing lest the question get lost). You want to know why he doesn't put down his bags, as you call them.
speaker: POZZO

line: (to Estragon). You are sure you agree with that?
speaker: POZZO

line: The answer is this. (To Estragon). But stay still, I beg of you, you're making me nervous!
speaker: POZZO

line: He's about to speak.Estragon goes over beside Vladimir. Motionless, side by side, they wait.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Good. Is everybody ready? Is everybody looking at me? (He looks at Lucky, jerks the rope. Lucky raises his head.) Will you look at me, pig! (Lucky looks at him.) Good. (He puts the pipe in his pocket, takes out a little vaporizer and sprays his throat, puts back the vaporizer in his pocket, clears his throat, spits, takes out the vaporizer again, sprays his throat again, puts back the vaporizer in his pocket.) I am ready. Is everybody listening? Is everybody ready? (He looks at them all in turn, jerks the rope.) Hog! (Lucky raises his head.) I don't like talking in a vacuum. Good. Let me see. He reflects.
speaker: POZZO

line: What was it exactly you wanted to know?
speaker: POZZO

line: (angrily). Don't interrupt me! (Pause. Calmer.) If we all speak at once we'll never get anywhere. (Pause.) What was I saying? (Pause. Louder.) What was I saying? Vladimir mimics one carrying a heavy burden. Pozzo looks at him, puzzled.
speaker: POZZO

line: (forcibly). Bags. (He points at Lucky.) Why? Always hold. (He sags, panting.) Never put down. (He opens his hands, straightens up with relief.) Why? POZZO:Ah! Why couldn't you say so before? Why he doesn't make himself comfortable? Let's try and get this clear. Has he not the right to? Certainly he has. It follows that he doesn't want to. There's reasoning for you. And why doesn't he want to? (Pause.) Gentlemen, the reason is this.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (to Estragon). Make a note of this.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: He wants to impress me, so that I'll keep him.
speaker: POZZO

line: Perhaps I haven't got it quite right. He wants to mollify me, so that I'll give up the idea of parting with him. No, that's not exactly it either.
speaker: POZZO

line: You want to get rid of him?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: He wants to con me, but he won't.
speaker: POZZO

line: You want to get rid of him?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: He imagines that when I see how well he carries I'll be tempted to keep him on in that capacity.
speaker: POZZO

line: In reality he carries like a pig. It's not his job. VLADIMIR:You want to get rid of him?
speaker: POZZO

line: He imagines that when I see him indefatigable I'll regret my decision. Such is his miserable scheme. As though I were short of slaves! (All three look at Lucky.) Atlas, son of Jupiter! (Silence.) Well, that's that, I think. Anything else? Vaporizer.
speaker: POZZO

line: You want to get rid of him?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Remark that I might just as well have been in his shoes and he in mine. If chance had not willed otherwise. To each one his due.
speaker: POZZO

line: You want to get rid of him?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I do. But instead of driving him away as I might have done, I mean instead of simply kicking him out on his arse, in the goodness of my heart I am bringing him to the fair, where I hope to get a good price for him. The truth is you can't drive such creatures away. The best thing would be to kill them. Lucky weeps.
speaker: POZZO

line: He's crying! POZZO:Old dogs have more dignity. (He proffers his handkerchief to Estragon.) Comfort him, since you pity him. (Estragon hesitates.) Come on. (Estragon takes the handkerchief.) Wipe away his tears, he'll feel less forsaken. Estragon hesitates.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Here, give it to me, I'll do it. Estragon refuses to give the handkerchief. Childish gestures.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Make haste, before he stops. (Estragon approaches Lucky and makes to wipe his eyes. Lucky kicks him violently in the shins. Estragon drops the handkerchief, recoils, staggers about the stage howling with pain.) Hanky! Lucky puts down bag and basket, picks up handkerchief and gives it to Pozzo, goes back to his place, picks up bag and basket.
speaker: POZZO

line: Oh the swine! (He pulls up the leg of his trousers.) He's crippled me!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I told you he didn't like strangers.
speaker: POZZO

line: (to Estragon). Show me. (Estragon shows his leg. To Pozzo, angrily.) He's bleeding!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (on one leg). I'll never walk again!VLADIMIR: (tenderly). I'll carry you. (Pause.) If necessary.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: He's stopped crying. (To Estragon.) You have replaced him as it were. (Lyrically.) The tears of the world are a constant quantity. For each one who begins to weep, somewhere else another stops. The same is true of the laugh. (He laughs.) Let us not then speak ill of our generation, it is not any unhappier than its predecessors. (Pause.) Let us not speak well of it either. (Pause.) Let us not speak of it at all. (Pause. Judiciously.) It is true the population has increased.
speaker: POZZO

line: Try and walk. Estragon takes a few limping steps, stops before Lucky and spits on him, then goes and sits down on the mound.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Guess who taught me all these beautiful things. (Pause. Pointing to Lucky.) My Lucky!
speaker: POZZO

line: (looking at the sky.) Will night never come?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: But for him all my thoughts, all my feelings, would have been of common things. (Pause. With extraordinary vehemence.) Professional worries! (Calmer.) Beauty, grace, truth of the first water, I knew they were all beyond me. So I took a knook.
speaker: POZZO

line: (startled from his inspection of the sky). A knook?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: That was nearly sixty years ago . . . (he consults his watch) . . . yes, nearly sixty. (Drawing himself up proudly.) You wouldn'tthink it to look at me, would you? Compared to him I look like a young man, no? (Pause.) Hat! (Lucky puts down the basket and takes off his hat. His long white hair falls about his face. He puts his hat under his arm and picks up the basket.) Now look. (Pozzo takes off his hat. [All four wear bowlers.] He is completely bald. He puts on his hat again.) Did you see?
speaker: POZZO

line: And now you turn him away? Such an old and faithful servant!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Swine! Pozzo more and more agitated.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: After having sucked all the good out of him you chuck him away like a . . . like a banana skin. Really . . .
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (groaning, clutching his head). I can't bear it . . . any longer . . . the way he goes on . . . you've no idea . . . it's terrible . . . he must go . . . (he waves his arms) . . . I'm going mad . . . (he collapses, his head in his hands) . . . I can't bear it . . . any longer . . . Silence. All look at Pozzo.
speaker: POZZO

line: It's terrible.VLADIMIR: (to Lucky). How dare you! It's abominable! Such a good master! Crucify him like that! After so many years! Really!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (sobbing). He used to be so kind . . . so helpful . . . and entertaining . . . my good angel . . . and now . . . he's killing me.
speaker: POZZO

line: ( to Vladimir). Does he want to replace him?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Does he want someone to take his place or not?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (calmer). Gentlemen, I don't know what came over me. Forgive me. Forget all I said. (More and more his old self.) I don't remember exactly what it was, but you may be sure there wasn't a word of truth in it. (Drawing himself up, striking his chest.) Do I look like a man that can be made to suffer? Frankly? (He rummages in his pockets.) What have I done with my pipe? VLADIMIR:Charming evening we're having.
speaker: POZZO

line: What can I have done with that briar?
speaker: POZZO

line: He's a scream. He's lost his dudeen. Laughs noisily.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I'll be back. He hastens towards the wings.ESTRAGON: End of the corridor, on the left.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (on the point of tears). I've lost my Kapp and Peterson!
speaker: POZZO

line: (convulsed with merriment). He'll be the death of me!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You didn't see by any chance– (He misses Vladimir.) Oh! He's gone! Without saying goodbye! How could he! He might have waited!
speaker: POZZO

line: Oh! (Pause.) Oh well then of course in that case . . .
speaker: POZZO

line: You want me to get up? ESTRAGON:Quick! (Pozzo gets up and goes over beside Estragon. Estragon points off.) Look!
speaker: POZZO

line: (having put on his glasses). Oh I say!
speaker: POZZO

line: It's all over. Enter Vladimir, somber. He shoulders Lucky out of his way, kicks over the stool, comes and goes agitatedly.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (to Vladimir). You missed a treat. Pity. Vladimir halts, straightens the stool, comes and goes, calmer.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: He subsides. (Looking round.) Indeed all subsides. A great calm descends. (Raising his hand.) Listen! Pan sleeps.
speaker: POZZO

line: Will night never come? All three look at the sky.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You don't feel like going until it does?
speaker: POZZO

line: Why it's very natural, very natural. I myself in your situation, if I had an appointment with a Godin . . . Godet . . . Godot . . . anyhow, you see who I mean, I'd wait till it was black night before I gave up. (He looks at the stool.) I'd very much like to sit down, but I don't quite know how to go about it.ESTRAGON: Could I be of any help?
speaker: POZZO

line: If you asked me to sit down.
speaker: POZZO

line: Here we go. Be seated, Sir, I beg of you.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: No no, I wouldn't think of it! (Pause. Aside.) Ask me again.
speaker: POZZO

line: Come come, take a seat I beseech you, you'll get pneumonia.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: No doubt you are right. (He sits down.) Done it again! (Pause.) Thank you, dear fellow. (He consults his watch.) But I must really be getting along, if I am to observe my schedule. VLADIMIR:Time has stopped.
speaker: POZZO

line: (cuddling his watch to his ear). Don't you believe it, Sir, don't you believe it. (He puts his watch back in his pocket.) Whatever you like, but not that.
speaker: POZZO

line: (to Pozzo). Everything seems black to him today.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Except the firmament. (He laughs, pleased with this witticism.) But I see what it is, you are not from these parts, you don't know what our twilights can do. Shall I tell you? (Silence. Estragon is fiddling with his boot again, Vladimir with his hat.) I can't refuse you. (Vaporizer.) A little attention, if you please. (Vladimir and Estragon continue their fiddling, Lucky is half asleep. Pozzo cracks his whip feebly.) What's the matter with this whip? (He gets up and cracks it more vigorously, finally with success. Lucky jumps. Vladimir's hat, Estragon's boot, Lucky's hat, fall to the ground. Pozzo throws down the whip.) Worn out, this whip. (He looks at Vladimir and Estragon.) What was I saying?
speaker: POZZO

line: But take the weight off your feet, I implore you, you'll catch your death.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: True. (He sits down. To Estragon.) What is your name?
speaker: POZZO

line: Adam. POZZO:(who hasn't listened). Ah yes! The night. (He raises his head.) But be a little more attentive, for pity's sake, otherwise we'll never get anywhere. (He looks at the sky.) Look! (All look at the sky except Lucky who is dozing off again. Pozzo jerks the rope.) Will you look at the sky, pig! (Lucky looks at the sky.) Good, that's enough. (They stop looking at the sky.) What is there so extraordinary about it? Qua sky. It is pale and luminous like any sky at this hour of the day. (Pause.) In these latitudes. (Pause.) When the weather is fine. (Lyrical.) An hour ago (he looks at his watch, prosaic) roughly (lyrical) after having poured forth even since (he hesitates, prosaic) say ten o'clock in the morning (lyrical) tirelessly torrents of red and white light it begins to lose its effulgence, to grow pale (gesture of the two hands lapsing by stages) pale, ever a little paler, a little paler until (dramatic pause, ample gesture of the two hands flung wide apart) pppfff! finished! it comes to rest. But– (hand raised in admonition)– but behind this veil of gentleness and peace, night is charging (vibrantly) and will burst upon us (snaps his fingers) pop! like that! (his inspiration leaves him) just when we least expect it. (Silence. Gloomily.) That's how it is on this bitch of an earth. Long silence.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Simply wait.VLADIMIR: We're used to it. He picks up his hat, peers inside it, shakes it, puts it on.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: How did you find me? (Vladimir and Estragon look at him blankly.) Good? Fair? Middling? Poor? Positively bad?
speaker: POZZO

line: (first to understand). Oh very good, very very good.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Oh tray bong, tray tray tray bong.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (fervently). Bless you, gentlemen, bless you! (Pause.) I have such need of encouragement! (Pause.) I weakened a little towards the end, you didn't notice?
speaker: POZZO

line: Oh perhaps just a teeny weeny little bit.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You see my memory is defective. Silence.
speaker: POZZO

line: I've been better entertained. Silence. Pozzo struggles inwardly.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Gentlemen, you have been . . . civil to me.
speaker: POZZO

line: Yes yes, you have been correct. So that I ask myself is there anything I can do in my turn for these honest fellows who are having such a dull, dull time.
speaker: POZZO

line: Even ten francs would be a help.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Is there anything I can do, that's what I ask myself, to cheer them up? I have given them bones, I have talked to them about this and that, I have explained the twilight, admittedly. But is it enough, that's what tortures me, is it enough?
speaker: POZZO

line: Even five.VLADIMIR: (to Estragon, indignantly). That's enough!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Is is enough? No doubt. But I am liberal. It's my nature. This evening. So much the worse for me. (He jerks the rope. Lucky looks at him.) For I shall suffer, no doubt about that. (He picks up the whip.) What do you prefer? Shall we have him dance, or sing, or recite, or think, or—
speaker: POZZO

line: Who! You know how to think, you two?
speaker: POZZO

line: Certainly. Aloud. He even used to think very prettily once, I could listen to him for hours. Now . . . (he shudders). So much the worse for me. Well, would you like him to think something for us?
speaker: POZZO

line: I'd rather he dance, it'd be more fun.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Wouldn't it, Didi, be more fun?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I'd like well to hear him think.ESTRAGON: Perhaps he could dance first and think afterwards, if it isn't too much to ask him.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: By all means, nothing simpler. It's the natural order. He laughs briefly.
speaker: POZZO

line: He refused once. (Silence.) Dance, misery! Lucky puts down bag and basket, advances towards front, turns to Pozzo. Lucky dances. He stops.
speaker: POZZO

line: Encore! Lucky executes the same movements, stops.
speaker: POZZO

line: Pooh! I'd do as well myself. (He imitates Lucky, almost falls.) With a little practice.POZZO: He used to dance the farandole, the fling, the brawl, the jig, the fandango and even the hornpipe. He capered. For joy. Now that's the best he can do. Do you know what he calls it?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: The Net. He thinks he's entangled in a net.
speaker: POZZO

line: (squirming like an aesthete). There's something about it . . . Lucky makes to return to his burdens.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Tell us about the time he refused.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: With pleasure, with pleasure. (He fumbles in his pockets.) Wait. (He fumbles.) What have I done with my spray? (He fumbles.) Well now isn't that . . . (He looks up, consternation on his features. Faintly.) I can't find my pulverizer!
speaker: POZZO

line: (faintly). My left lung is very weak! (He coughs feebly. In ringing tones.) But my right lung is as sound as a bell! POZZO:(normal voice). No matter! What was I saying. (He ponders.) Wait. (Ponders.) Well now isn't that . . . (He raises his head.) Help me!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Wait! All three take off their hats simultaneously, press their hands to their foreheads, concentrate.
speaker: POZZO

line: Why doesn't he put down his bags?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Damn it haven't you already told us?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I've already told you?ESTRAGON: He's already told us?
speaker: POZZO

line: Anyway he has put them down.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (glance at Lucky). So he has. And what of it?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Since he has put down his bags it is impossible we should have asked why he does not do so.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: And why has he put them down?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: True! Silence. They put on their hats.
speaker: POZZO

line: Nothing happens, nobody comes, nobody goes, it's awful!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (to Pozzo). Tell him to think. POZZO:Give him his hat.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: He can't think without his hat.
speaker: POZZO

line: Me! After what he did to me! Never!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I'll give it to him. He does not move.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (to Pozzo). Tell him to go and fetch it.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: It's better to give it to him.
speaker: POZZO

line: I'll give it to him. He picks up the hat and tenders it at arm's length to Lucky, who does not move.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You must put it on his head.
speaker: POZZO

line: (to Pozzo). Tell him to take it.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: It's better to put it on his head. VLADIMIR:I'll put it on his head. He goes round behind Lucky, approaches him cautiously, puts the hat on his head and recoils smartly. Lucky does not move. Silence.
speaker: POZZO

line: Stand back! (Vladimir and Estragon move away from Lucky. Pozzo jerks the rope. Lucky looks at Pozzo.) Think, pig! (Pause. Lucky begins to dance.) Stop! (Lucky stops.) Forward! (Lucky advances.) Stop! (Lucky stops.) Think! Silence.
speaker: POZZO

line: On the other hand with regard to—
speaker: LUCKY

line: Stop! (Lucky stops.) Back! (Lucky moves back.) Stop! (Lucky stops.) Turn! (Lucky turns towards auditorium.) Think! During Lucky's tirade the others react as follows. 1) Vladimir and Estragon all attention, Pozzo dejected and disgusted. 2) Vladimir and Estragon begin to protest, Pozzo's sufferings increase. 3) Vladimir and Estragon attentive again, Pozzo more and more agitated and groaning. 4) Vladimir and Estragon protest violently. Pozzo jumps up, pulls on the rope. General outcry. Lucky pulls on the rope, staggers, shouts his text. All three throw themselves on Lucky who struggles and shouts his text. LUCKY:Given the existence as uttered forth in the public works of Puncher and Wattmann of a personal God quaquaquaqua with white beard quaquaquaqua outside time without extension who from the heights of divine apathia divine athambia divine aphasia loves us dearly with some exceptions for reasons unknown but time will tell and suffers like the divine Miranda with those who for reasons unknown but time will tell are plunged in torment plunged in fire whose fire flames if that continues and who can doubt it will fire the firmament that is to say blast hell to heaven so blue still and calm so calm with a calm which even though intermittent is better than nothing but not so fast and considering what is more that as a result of the labors left unfinished crowned by the Acacacacademy of Anthropopopometry of Essy-in-Possy of Testew and Cunard it is established beyond all doubt all other doubt than that which clings to the labors of men that as a result of the labors unfinished of Testew and Cunnard it is established as hereinafter but not so fast for reasons unknown that as a result of the public works of Puncher and Wattmann it is established beyond all doubt that in view of the labors of Fartov and Belcher left unfinished for reasons unknown of Testew and Cunard left unfinished it is established what many deny that man in Possy of Testew and Cunard that man in Essy that man in short that man in brief in spite of the strides of alimentation and defecation wastes and pines wastes and pines and concurrently simultaneously what is more for reasons unknown in spite of the strides of physical culture the practice of sports such as tennis football running cycling swimming flying floating riding gliding conating camogie skating tennis of all kinds dying flying sports of all sorts autumn summer winter winter tennis of all kinds hockey of all sorts penicillin and succedanea in a word I resume flying gliding golf over nine and eighteen holes tennis of all sorts in a word for reasons unknown in Feckham Peckham Fulham Clapham namely concurrently simultaneously what is more for reasons unknown but time will tell fades away I resumeFulham Clapham in a word the dead loss per head since the death of Bishop Berkeley being to the tune of one inch four ounce per head approximately by and large more or less to the nearest decimal good measure round figures stark naked in the stockinged feet in Connemara in a word for reasons unknown no matter what matter the facts are there and considering what is more much more grave that in the light of the labors lost of Steinweg and Peterman it appears what is more much more grave that in the light the light the light of the labors lost of Steinweg and Peterman that in the plains in the mountains by the seas by the rivers running water running fire the air is the same and then the earth namely the air and then the earth in the great cold the great dark the air and the earth abode of stones in the great cold alas alas in the year of their Lord six hundred and something the air the earth the sea the earth abode of stones in the great deeps the great cold on sea on land and in the air I resume for reasons unknown in spite of the tennis the facts are there but time will tell I resume alas alas on on in short in fine on on abode of stones who can doubt it I resume but not so fast I resume the skull fading fading fading and concurrently simultaneously what is more for reasons unknown in spite of the tennis on on the beard the flames the tears the stones so blue so calm alas alas on on the skull the skull the skull the skull in Connemara in spite of the tennis the labors abandoned left unfinished graver still abode of stones in a word I resume alas alas abandoned unfinished the skull the skull in Connemara in spite of the tennis the skull alas the stones Cunard (mêlée, final vociferations) tennis . . . the stones . . . so calm . . . Cunard . . . unfinished . . .
speaker: POZZO

line: His hat! Vladimir seizes Lucky's hat. Silence of Lucky. He falls. Silence. Panting of the victors. ESTRAGON:Avenged! Vladimir examines the hat, peers inside it.
speaker: POZZO

line: Give me that! (He snatches the hat from Vladimir, throws it on the ground, tramples on it.) There's an end to his thinking!
speaker: POZZO

line: But will he be able to walk?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Walk or crawl! (He kicks Lucky.) Up pig!
speaker: POZZO

line: Up scum! (He jerks the rope.) Help me!
speaker: POZZO

line: Raise him up! Vladimir and Estragon hoist Lucky to his feet, support him an instant, then let him go. He falls.
speaker: POZZO

line: You must hold him. (Pause.) Come on, come on, raise him up.
speaker: POZZO

line: To hell with him!VLADIMIR: Come on, once more.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: What does he take us for? They raise Lucky, hold him up.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Don't let him go! (Vladimir and Estragon totter.) Don't move! (Pozzo fetches bag and basket and brings them towards Lucky.) Hold him tight! (He puts the bag in Lucky's hand. Lucky drops it immediately.) Don't let him go! (He puts back the bag in Lucky's hand. Gradually, at the feel of the bag, Lucky recovers his senses and his fingers finally close round the handle.) Hold him tight! (As before with basket.) # Now! You can let him go. (Vladimir and Estragon move away from Lucky who totters, reels, sags, but succeeds in remaining on his feet, bag and basket in his hands. Pozzo steps back, cracks his whip.) Forward! (Lucky totters forward.) Back! (Lucky totters back.) Turn! (Lucky turns.) Done it! He can walk. (Turning to Vladimir and Estragon.) Thank you, gentlemen, and let me . . . (he fumbles in his pockets) . . . let me wish you . . . (fumbles) . . . wish you . . . (fumbles) . . . what have I done with my watch? (Fumbles.) A genuine half-hunter, gentlemen, with deadbeat escapement! (Sobbing.) Twas my granpa gave it to me! (He searches on the ground, Vladimir and Estragon likewise. Pozzo turns over with his foot the remains of Lucky's hat.) Well now isn't that just—
speaker: POZZO

line: Wait! (He doubles up in an attempt to apply his ear to his stomach, listens. Silence.) I hear nothing. (He beckons them toapproach, Vladimir and Estragon go over to him, bend over his stomach.) Surely one should hear the tick-tick.
speaker: POZZO

line: Perhaps it has stopped. They straighten up.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Which of you smells so bad?
speaker: POZZO

line: He has stinking breath and I have stinking feet.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: And your half-hunter? POZZO:I must have left it at the manor. Silence.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I don't seem to be able . . . (long hesitation) . . . to depart.
speaker: POZZO

line: Such is life. Pozzo turns, moves away from Lucky towards the wings, paying out the rope as he goes.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I need a running start. (Having come to the end of the rope, i.e., off stage, he stops, turns and cries.) Stand back! (Vladimir and Estragon stand back, look towards Pozzo. Crack of whip.) On! On!
speaker: POZZO

line: Faster! (He appears, crosses the stage preceded by Lucky. Vladimir and Estragon wave their hats. Exit Lucky.) On! On! (On the point of disappearing in his turn he stops and turns. The rope tautens. Noise of Lucky falling off.) Stool! (Vladimirfetches stool and gives it to Pozzo who throws it to Lucky.) Adieu! VLADIMIR and ESTRAGON: (waving). Adieu! Adieu!
speaker: POZZO

line: Up! Pig! (Noise of Lucky getting up.) On! (Exit Pozzo.) Faster! On! Adieu! Pig! Yip! Adieu! Long silence.
speaker: POZZO

line: It would have passed in any case.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Yes, but not so rapidly. Pause.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: We're waiting for Godot.ESTRAGON: (despairingly). Ah! Pause.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: That's the idea, let's make a little conversation.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Very likely. They all change. Only we can't.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Likely! It's certain. Didn't you see them?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I suppose I did. But I don't know them.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: No I don't know them.VLADIMIR: We know them, I tell you. You forget everything. (Pause. To himself.) Unless they're not the same . . .
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Why didn't they recognize us then?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: That means nothing. I too pretended not to recognize them. And then nobody ever recognizes us.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Forget it. What we need– Ow! (Vladimir does not react.) Ow!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (to himself). Unless they're not the same . . .
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Didi! It's the other foot! He goes hobbling towards the mound.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (off). Mister! Estragon halts. Both look towards the voice.
speaker: BOY

line: Approach, my child. Enter Boy, timidly. He halts.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Approach! The Boy does not move.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (forcibly). Approach when you're told, can't you? The Boy advances timidly, halts.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (violently). Will you approach! (The Boy advances timidly.) What kept you so late?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You have a message from Mr. Godot?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: What kept you so late?The Boy looks at them in turn, not knowing to which he should reply.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (violently). You let me alone. (Advancing, to the Boy.) Do you know what time it is?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Afraid of what? Of us? (Pause.) Answer me!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I know what it is, he was afraid of the others.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: How long have you been here?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You were afraid of the whip?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Are you a native of these parts? (Silence.) Do you belong to these parts?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: That's all a pack of lies. (Shaking the Boy by the arm.) Tell us the truth!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (trembling). But it is the truth, Sir!
speaker: BOY

line: Will you let him alone! What's the matter with you? # (Estragon releases the Boy, moves away, covering his face with his hands. Vladimir and the Boy observe him. Estragon drops his hands. His face is convulsed.) What's the matter with you?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I'm unhappy. VLADIMIR:Not really! Since when?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Extraordinary the tricks that memory plays! (Estragon tries to speak, renounces, limps to his place, sits down and begins to take off his boots. To Boy.) Well?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I've seen you before, haven't I?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Yes Sir. Silence. VLADIMIR:Words words. (Pause.) Speak.
speaker: BOY

line: (in a rush). Mr. Godot told me to tell you he won't come this evening but surely tomorrow. Silence.
speaker: BOY

line: No Sir, not me. VLADIMIR:Whom does he beat?
speaker: BOY

line: And why doesn't he beat you?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: He must be fond of you.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Does he give you enough to eat? (The Boy hesitates.) Does he feed you well?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You're not unhappy? (The Boy hesitates.) Do you hear me?BOY: Yes Sir.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You don't know if you're unhappy or not?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You're as bad as myself. (Silence.) Where do you sleep?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: What am I to tell Mr. Godot, Sir?VLADIMIR: Tell him . . . (he hesitates) . . . tell him you saw us. (Pause.) You did see us, didn't you?
speaker: BOY

line: Yes Sir. He steps back, hesitates, turns and exit running. The light suddenly fails. In a moment it is night. The moon rises at back, mounts in the sky, stands still, shedding a pale light on the scene.
speaker: BOY

line: At last! (Estragon gets up and goes towards Vladimir, a boot in each hand. He puts them down at edge of stage, straightens and contemplates the moon.) # What are you doing?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Of climbing heaven and gazing on the likes of us.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Your boots, what are you doing with your boots?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (turning to look at the boots). I'm leaving them there. (Pause.) Another will come, just as . . . as . . . as me, but with smaller feet, and they'll make him happy.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: But you can't go barefoot! ESTRAGON:Christ did.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Christ! What has Christ got to do with it. You're not going to compare yourself to Christ!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: All my life I've compared myself to him.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: But where he lived it was warm, it was dry!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Yes. And they crucified quick. Silence.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: We've nothing more to do here.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Ah Gogo, don't go on like that. Tomorrow everything will be better.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: How do you make that out?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Did you not hear what the child said?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: He said that Godot was sure to come tomorrow. (Pause.) What do you say to that?ESTRAGON: Then all we have to do is to wait on here.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Are you mad? We must take cover. (He takes Estragon by the arm.) Come on. He draws Estragon after him. Estragon yields, then resists. They halt.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (looking at the tree). Pity we haven't got a bit of rope.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Come on. It's cold. He draws Estragon after him. As before.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Remind me to bring a bit of rope tomorrow.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Yes. Come on. He draws him after him. As before.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: How long have we been together all the time now?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I don't know. Fifty years maybe.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Do you remember the day I threw myself into the Rhone?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You fished me out.VLADIMIR: That's all dead and buried.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: My clothes dried in the sun.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: There's no good harking back on that. Come on. He draws him after him. As before.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Wait! (He moves away from Vladimir.) I sometimes wonder if we wouldn't have been better off alone, each one for himself. (He crosses the stage and sits down on the mound.) We weren't made for the same road.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: No, nothing is certain. Vladimir slowly crosses the stage and sits down beside Estragon. #
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: We can still part, if you think it would be better.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: It's not worthwhile now. Silence. VLADIMIR:No, it's not worthwhile now. Silence.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Yes, let's go. They do not move. Curtain. Next day. Same time. Same place. Estragon's boots front center, heels together, toes splayed. Lucky's hat at same place. The tree has four or five leaves. Enter Vladimir agitatedly. He halts and looks long at the tree, then suddenly begins to move feverishly about the stage. He halts before the boots, picks one up, examines it, sniffs it, manifests disgust, puts it back carefully. Comes and goes. Halts extreme right and gazes into distance off, shading his eyes with his hand. Comes and goes. Halts extreme left, as before. Comes and goes. Halts suddenly and begins to sing loudly.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: A dog came in– Having begun too high he stops, clears his throat, resumes:A dog came in the kitchen And stole a crust of bread. Then cook up with a ladle And beat him till he was dead. Then all the dogs came running And dug the dog a tomb– He stops, broods, resumes: Then all the dogs came running And dug the dog a tomb And wrote upon the tombstone For the eyes of dogs to come: A dog came in the kitchen And stole a crust of bread. Then cook up with a ladle And beat him till he was dead. Then all the dogs came running And dug the dog a tomb– He stops, broods, resumes: Then all the dogs came running And dug the dog a tomb– He stops, broods. Softly. And dug the dog a tomb . . . He remains a moment silent and motionless, then begins to move feverishly about the stage. He halts before the tree, comes and goes, before the boots, comes and goes, halts extreme right, gazes into distance, extreme left, gazes into distance. Enter Estragon right, barefoot, head bowed. He slowly crosses the stage. Vladimir turns and sees him. VLADIMIR:You again! (Estragon halts but does not raise his head. Vladimir goes towards him.) Come here till I embrace you.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Don't touch me! Vladimir holds back, pained.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Do you want me to go away? (Pause.) Gogo! (Pause. Vladimir observes him attentively.) Did they beat you? (Pause.) Gogo! (Estragon remains silent, head bowed.) Where did you spend the night?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Don't touch me! Don't question me! Don't speak to me! Stay with me!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Look at me. (Estragon does not raise his head. Violently.) Will you look at me! Estragon raises his head. They look long at each other, then suddenly embrace, clapping each other on the back. End of the embrace. Estragon, no longer supported, almost falls.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Another day done with.VLADIMIR: Not yet.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: For me it's over and done with, no matter what happens. (Silence.) I heard you singing.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: That finished me. I said to myself, He's all alone, he thinks I'm gone for ever, and he sings.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: One is not master of one's moods. All day I've felt in great form. (Pause.) I didn't get up in the night, not once!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (sadly). You see, you piss better when I'm not there.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I missed you . . . and at the same time I was happy. Isn't that a strange thing?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Perhaps it's not quite the right word.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Now? . . . (Joyous.) There you are again . . . (Indifferent.) There we are again. . . (Gloomy.) There I am again. ESTRAGON:You see, you feel worse when I'm with you. I feel better alone too.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (vexed). Then why do you always come crawling back?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: No, but I do. It's because you don't know how to defend yourself. I wouldn't have let them beat you.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: No, I mean before they beat you. I would have stopped you from doing whatever it was you were doing.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Then why did they beat you?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Ah no, Gogo, the truth is there are things that escape you that don't escape me, you must feel it yourself. ESTRAGON:I tell you I wasn't doing anything.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Perhaps you weren't. But it's the way of doing it that counts, the way of doing it, if you want to go on living.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You must be happy too, deep down, if you only knew it.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: To be back with me again.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Say you are, even if it's not true.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: So am I. VLADIMIR:We are happy.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: We are happy. (Silence.) What do we do now, now that we are happy?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Wait for Godot. (Estragon groans. Silence.) Things have changed here since yesterday.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (after a moment of bewilderment). We'll see when the time comes. (Pause.) I was saying that things have changed here since yesterday.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: It's never the same pus from one second to the next.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: The tree, look at the tree. Estragon looks at the tree.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Yes of course it was there. Do you not remember? We nearly hanged ourselves from it. But you wouldn't. Do you not remember?ESTRAGON: You dreamt it.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Is it possible you've forgotten already?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: That's the way I am. Either I forget immediately or I never forget.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: And Pozzo and Lucky, have you forgotten them too?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I remember a lunatic who kicked the shins off me. Then he played the fool.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I remember that. But when was it?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: And his keeper, do you not remember him?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: That was Pozzo. ESTRAGON:And all that was yesterday, you say?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Yes of course it was yesterday.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: And here where we are now?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Where else do you think? Do you not recognize the place?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (suddenly furious). Recognize! What is there to recognize? All my lousy life I've crawled about in the mud! And you talk to me about scenery! (Looking wildly about him.) Look at this muckheap! I've never stirred from it!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You and your landscapes! Tell me about the worms!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: All the same, you can't tell me that this (gesture) bears any resemblance to . . . (he hesitates) . . . to the Macon country for example. You can't deny there's a big difference.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: The Macon country! Who's talking to you about the Macon country?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: But you were there yourself, in the Macon country.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: No I was never in the Macon country! I've puked my puke of a life away here, I tell you! Here! In the Cackon country! VLADIMIR:But we were there together, I could swear to it! Picking grapes for a man called . . . (he snaps his fingers) . . . can't think of the name of the man, at a place called . . . (snaps his fingers) . . . can't think of the name of the place, do you not remember?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (a little calmer). It's possible. I didn't notice anything.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: But down there everything is red!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (exasperated). I didn't notice anything, I tell you! Silence. Vladimir sighs deeply.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You're a hard man to get on with, Gogo.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: It'd be better if we parted.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You always say that and you always come crawling back.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: The best thing would be to kill me, like the other.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (sententious). To every man his little cross. (He sighs.) Till he dies. (Afterthought.) And is forgotten. ESTRAGON:In the meantime let us try and converse calmly, since we are incapable of keeping silent.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: They make a noise like wings.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: To have lived is not enough for them.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: They have to talk about it.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: To be dead is not enough for them.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: They make a noise like feathers.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: No no! (He reflects.) We could start all over again perhaps.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: That should be easy.VLADIMIR: It's the start that's difficult.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Yes, but you have to decide.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You think all the same. VLADIMIR:No no, it's impossible.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: That's the idea, let's contradict each another.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: We're in no danger of ever thinking any more.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Then what are we complaining about?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Perhaps not. But at least there's that.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: That's the idea, let's ask each other questions.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: What do you mean, at least there's that?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Well? If we gave thanks for our mercies?VLADIMIR: What is terrible is to have thought.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: But did that ever happen to us?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Where are all these corpses from?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: We must have thought a little.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Try as one may. ESTRAGON:I beg your pardon?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: We should turn resolutely towards Nature.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: On it's not the worst, I know.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: But we could have done without it.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: That wasn't such a bad little canter.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Yes, but now we'll have to find something else.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Let me see. He takes off his hat, concentrates.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Let me see. (He takes off his hat, concentrates. Long silence.) Ah! They put on their hats, relax.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: What was I saying, we could go on from there.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: This evening . . . I was saying . . . I was saying . . .
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I'm not a historian. VLADIMIR:Wait . . . we embraced . . . we were happy . . . happy . . . what do we do now that we're happy . . . go on waiting . . . waiting . . . let me think . . . it's coming . . . go on waiting . . . now that we're happy . . . let me see . . . ah! The tree!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Look at it. They look at the tree.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: But yesterday evening it was all black and bare. And now it's covered with leaves.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: But in a single night! ESTRAGON:I tell you we weren't here yesterday. Another of your nightmares.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: And where were we yesterday evening according to you?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: How would I know? In another compartment. There's no lack of void.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (sure of himself). Good. We weren't here yesterday evening. Now what did we do yesterday evening?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Oh . . . this and that I suppose, nothing in particular. (With assurance.) Yes, now I remember, yesterday evening we spent blathering about nothing in particular. That's been going on now for half a century.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You don't remember any fact, any circumstance?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (weary). Don't torment me, Didi. VLADIMIR:The sun. The moon. Do you not remember?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: They must have been there, as usual.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You didn't notice anything out of the ordinary?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: It was Pozzo gave them to you.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: That's right, someone gave me a kick.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: It was Lucky gave it to you.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: And all that was yesterday?VLADIMIR: Show me your leg.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Both. Pull up your trousers. (Estragon gives a leg to Vladimir, staggers. Vladimir takes the leg. They stagger.) Pull up your trousers.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I can't. Vladimir pulls up the trousers, looks at the leg, lets it go. Estragon almost falls.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: The other. (Estragon gives the same leg.) The other, pig! (Estragon gives the other leg. Triumphantly.) There's the wound! Beginning to fester!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (letting go the leg). Where are your boots?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I must have thrown them away.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Why?ESTRAGON: (exasperated). I don't know why I don't know!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: No, I mean why did you throw them away?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (triumphantly, pointing to the boots). There they are! (Estragon looks at the boots.) At the very spot where you left them yesterday! Estragon goes towards the boots, inspects them closely.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Mine were black. These are brown.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Well they were a kind of gray.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: And these are brown. Show me.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (picking up a boot). Well they're a kind of green. VLADIMIR:Show me. (Estragon hands him the boot. Vladimir inspects it, throws it down angrily.) Well of all the—
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: You see, all that's a lot of bloody—
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Ah! I see what it is. Yes, I see what's happened.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: All that's a lot of bloody—
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: It's elementary. Someone came and took yours and left you his.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: His were too tight for him, so he took yours.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (having tried in vain to work it out). I'm tired! (Pause.) Let's go.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: We're waiting for Godot.ESTRAGON: Ah! (Pause. Despairing.) What'll we do, what'll we do!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: But I can't go on like this!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: No. Anyway you overdo it with your carrots.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Then give me a radish. (Vladimir fumbles in his pockets, finds nothing but turnips, finally brings out a radish and hands it to Estragon who examines it, sniffs it.) It's black!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: I only like the pink ones, you know that!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Then you don't want it? ESTRAGON:I only like the pink ones!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Then give it back to me. Estragon gives it back.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I'll go and get a carrot. He does not move.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Would that be a good thing?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: It'd pass the time. (Estragon hesitates.) I assure you, it'd be an occupation.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: We don't manage too badly, eh Didi, between the two of us?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Yes yes. Come on, we'll try the left first.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: We always find something, eh Didi, to give us the impression we exist?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (impatiently). Yes yes, we're magicians. But let us persevere in what we have resolved, before we forget. (He picks up a boot.) Come on, give me your foot. (Estragon raises his foot.) The other, hog! (Estragon raises the other foot.) Higher! # (Wreathed together they stagger about the stage. Vladimir succeeds finally in getting on the boot.) Try and walk. (Estragon walks.) Well?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (taking string from his pocket). We'll try and lace it. ESTRAGON:(vehemently). No no, no laces, no laces!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You'll be sorry. Let's try the other. (As before.) Well?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Perhaps you'll have socks some day.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (violently). Enough! (Silence.) I suppose I might as well sit down.He looks for a place to sit down, then goes and sits down on the mound.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: That's where you were sitting yesterday evening.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I'll try. He resumes his foetal posture, his head between his knees.
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Wait. (He goes over and sits down beside Estragon and begins to sing in a loud voice.) Bye bye bye bye Bye bye– #
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: (softly). Bye bye bye bye Bye bye bye bye Bye bye bye bye Bye bye . . . Estragon sleeps. Vladimir gets up softly, takes off his coat and lays it across Estragon's shoulders, then starts walking up and down, swinging his arms to keep himself warm. Estragon wakes with a start, jumps up, casts about wildly. Vladimir runs to him, puts his arms around him.) There . . . there . . . Didi is here . . . don't be afraid . . .ESTRAGON: Ah!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: It's all over, it's all over.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I was on top of a—
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: Don't tell me! Come, we'll walk it off. He takes Estragon by the arm and walks him up and down until Estragon refuses to go any further.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: You'd rather be stuck there doing nothing?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Please yourself. He releases Estragon, picks up his coat and puts it on.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Ah! (Vladimir walks up and down.) Can you not stay still?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: It'll fall all of a sudden, like yesterday.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Then it'll be day again. (Pause. Despairing.) What'll we do, what'll we do!
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: (halting, violently). Will you stop whining! I've had about my bellyful of your lamentations! ESTRAGON:I'm going.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Lucky's hat. (He goes towards it.) I've been here an hour and never saw it. (Very pleased.) Fine!
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I knew it was the right place. Now our troubles are over. (He picks up the hat, contemplates it, straightens it.) Must have been a very fine hat. (He puts it on in place of his own which he hands to Estragon.) Here.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Hold that. Estragon takes Vladimir's hat. Vladimir adjusts Lucky's hat on his head. Estragon puts on Vladimir's hat in place of his own which he hands to Vladimir. Vladimir takes Estragon's hat. Estragon adjusts Vladimir's hat on his head. Vladimir puts on Estragon's hat in place of Lucky's which he hands to Estragon. Estragon takes Lucky's hat. Vladimir adjusts Estragon's hat on his head. Estragon puts on Lucky's hat in place of Vladimir's which he hands to Vladimir. Vladimir takes his hat, Estragon adjusts Lucky's hat on his head. Vladimir puts on his hat in place of Estragon's which he hands to Estragon. Estragon takes his hat. Vladimir adjusts his hat on his head. Estragon puts on his hat in place of Lucky'swhich he hands to Vladimir. Vladimir takes Lucky's hat. Estragon adjusts his hat on his head. Vladimir puts on Lucky's hat in place of his own which he hands to Estragon. Estragon takes Vladimir's hat. Vladimir adjusts Lucky's hat on his head. Estragon hands Vladimir's hat back to Vladimir who takes it and hands it back to Estragon who takes it and hands it back to Vladimir who takes it and throws it down. How does it fit me?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: No, but how do I look in it? He turns his head coquettishly to and fro, minces like a mannequin.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Yes, but not more so than usual?
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: Then I can keep it. Mine irked me. (Pause.) How shall I say? (Pause.) It itched me. He takes off Lucky's hat, peers into it, shakes it, knocks on the crown, puts it on again.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I'm going. Silence. VLADIMIR:Will you not play?
speaker: ESTRAGON

line: We could play at Pozzo and Lucky.
speaker: VLADIMIR

line: I'll do Lucky, you do Pozzo. (He imitates Lucky sagging under the weight of his baggage. Estragon looks at him with stupefaction.) Go on.
speaker: VLADIMIR
